titleStmt.title: A Description of Dr Delanys Villa

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: by Mr. Sheriden
Would you that Dellville I describe?
Beleive me Sir I will not gibe
For who woud be Satyricall
Upon a thing so very small?
You scarce upon the borders enter,
Before you're in the very Centre
A single Crow can make it night
When ore yr farm he takes his flight
Yet in this narrow compass we
Observe a vast Variety?
Both Walks, Walls Meadows & Parterres,
Windows and Doors, and rooms and Stairs
And Hills, and Dales, and Woods and Feilds
And Hay and Grass and Corn it yeilds
All to yr Haggard brought so cheap in
Without the Mowing or the reaping
A Razour, tho to say't Ime loath
Woud shave you and yr Meadows both.
Tho smalls the farm yet heres a house
Full large to entertain a Mouse
But where a Cat is dreaded more
Than Salvage Caledonian Boar
For if tis enterd by a Rat
There is no room to bring a Cat.
A little Rivalet seems to Steal
Down thro a thing you call yr Vale
Like tears along a wrinkld Cheek,
Like rain along a blade of Leek
And this you call yr sweet Meander
Wch might be suckd up by a Gander
Coud he but force his Nestling bill
To scoop the Channel of the Rill
Ime sure you'd make a mighty Clutter
Were it as big as Citty Gutter.
Next come I to yr Kitchen──────Garden
Where one poor Mouse woud fare but hard in
And round this Garden is a walk
No longer then a Taylors chalk
Thus I compute what space is in it
A Snail creeps round it in a minuit,
One Lettice makes a Shift to squeeze
Up thro a Tuft you call yr Trees
And once a year a single Rose
Peeps from the bud, but never blows
In vain then you expect its bloom
It cannot blow for want of roomIn short in all yr boasted Seat
Theres nothing but yr Self, thats GreatY07B600B
